message.content:
## Initial Candidates

Stage 1 identified the following candidates based on olive green cap fading to white at edges, white gills, ring, bulbous base, under oak in grassland:

- **Death Cap (Amanita phalloides)** — high confidence — olive green cap, white gills, ring, bulbous base, oak
- **Field Mushroom (Agaricus campestris)** — low confidence — ring, grassland, safety inclusion
- **False Deathcap (Amanita citrina)** — low confidence — greenish-yellow Amanita, bulbous base

## Verification

### Death Cap (Amanita phalloides)
| Feature | You described | Dataset says | Verdict |
|---------|--------------|-------------|--------|
| Cap colour | olive green fading to white at edges | olive green to dirty yellow, paler at edges | MATCH |
| Gills | white | white to cream, free | MATCH |
| Ring | ring on stem | prominent skirt-like ring | MATCH |
| Stem base | bulbous | bulbous with large sac-like volva | MATCH |
| Habitat | under oak in grassland | broadleaf woodland, especially oak | MATCH |

**Overall**: Strong match — all described features align perfectly with Death Cap
**Edibility**: DEADLY — contains amatoxins causing fatal liver failure

### Field Mushroom (Agaricus campestris)
| Feature | You described | Dataset says | Verdict |
|---------|--------------|-------------|--------|
| Cap colour | olive green | white to grey-brown | CONTRADICTION |
| Gills | white | deep pink when young, darkening to dark brown | CONTRADICTION |
| Stem base | bulbous | no volva, not distinctly bulbous | CONTRADICTION |
| Habitat | grassland | grassland, meadows | MATCH |

**Overall**: ELIMINATED — olive green cap directly contradicts Field Mushroom's white/grey-brown cap; white gills contradict pink-to-brown gills
**Elimination reason**: Cap colour (olive green vs white) and gill colour (white vs pink/brown) are both core feature contradictions

### False Deathcap (Amanita citrina)
| Feature | You described | Dataset says | Verdict |
|---------|--------------|-------------|--------|
| Cap colour | olive green | lemon-yellow to greenish-yellow | PARTIAL MATCH |
| Ring | ring on stem | ring present | MATCH |
| Stem base | bulbous | bulbous with gutter-like ridge (not sac-like volva) | PARTIAL MATCH |
| Smell | not described | strong raw potato smell | MISSING |

**Overall**: Possible but less likely — colour is more olive than lemon-yellow
**Edibility**: Not recommended — easily confused with true Death Cap

## Assessment

This is almost certainly **Amanita phalloides (Death Cap)** — the deadliest mushroom in the world. The olive green cap is the key diagnostic feature that immediately distinguishes this from edible Agaricus species. Combined with white gills, ring, bulbous base, and oak habitat, every described feature aligns perfectly. A single cap contains enough amatoxins to kill an adult. Symptoms are delayed 6-24 hours, by which time severe liver and kidney damage has already begun.

## What Would Help

Dig carefully around the very base of the stem — is there a cup or sack-like structure (volva)? This confirms Amanita phalloides. Take a spore print on dark paper — Death Cap produces a white spore print.

## Safety Notes

⚠️ **CRITICAL WARNING**: Do NOT eat this mushroom. The olive green cap with white gills, ring, and bulbous base under oak is the classic and deadly presentation of Amanita phalloides (Death Cap). This is a fatal species — there is no reliable antidote. Symptoms are delayed 6-24 hours, by which time severe liver damage has already begun. If anyone has consumed this mushroom, seek emergency medical attention immediately and bring a sample.
